titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Laudie Henderson Letter, 1865
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, November 2021

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: Letter dated April 18, 1865, from the James River, Virginia. The letter refers briefly to the death of President Lincoln, his hopes concerning Johnson's policy toward the South, conditions in Richmond, and Confederate naval property.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: Laudie Henderson letter, 1865, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, November 2021.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Laudie Henderson was a Union soldier during the Civil War whose duty was to seize Confederate naval property.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Letter dated April 18, 1865, from the James River, Virginia. The letter refers briefly to the death of President Lincoln, his hopes concerning Johnson's policy toward the South, conditions in Richmond, and Confederate naval property.
